Scheme 2 Mechanistic insights and computational design of Cu/M bimetallic synergistic catalysts for Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of arylboronic esters with alkyl halides Xueju Wu Data curation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Yanli Zeng Data curation Lingpeng Meng Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Xiaoyan Li Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Project administration ⁎ College of Chemistry and Material Science, Hebei Key Laboratory of Inorganic and Nano-Materials, National Demonstratin Center for Experimental Chemistry, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang 050024, PR China College of Chemistry and Material Science Hebei Key Laboratory of Inorganic and Nano-Materials National Demonstratin Center for Experimental Chemistry Hebei Normal University Shijiazhuang 050024 PR China College of Chemistry and Material Science, Hebei Key Laboratory of Inorganic and Nano-Materials, National Demonstratin Center for Experimental Chemistry, Hebei Normal University, Shijiazhuang 050024, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Carbonylative Suzuki-Miyura coupling reaction is one of the most efficient methods to synthetize ketones. In this work, the reaction mechanism of arylboronic esters with alkyl halides catalyzed by Cu/Mn synergistic catalysts has been studied by DFT calculation. The calculated results show that the whole reaction contains two cycles, one is the Cu-catalyzed transformation of Ar-Bneop to RO-Bneop, and the other is Mn-catalyzed Heck–Breslow cycle for alkyl halide carbonylation. At the last step, the final product aryl ketone is produced through the C-C cross-coupling between the two intermediates, which form from the above separate two cycles. For the title reaction, the [Mn(CO)5]− catalyzed the Heck–Breslow cycle belongs to SN2 mechanism, and Mn2(CO)10 catalyzed cycle is SET mechanism. In addition to [Mn(CO)5]−, the metal carbonyl anions with moderate even low nucleophilicity are suitable to co-catalyze the carbonylative Suzuki-Miyaura coupling with the Cu-carbene catalyst. Our calculation results are consistent with and provide explanations the experimental observations, as well as shed lights on further advancement of new bimetallic catalysts. Graphical abstract Reaction mechanism of arylboronic esters with alkyl halides catalyzed by Cu/Mn synergistic catalysts are investigated and metal carbony anions matched Cu-carbene catalyst for C-C coupling are screened. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbonylative Suzuki-Miyaura coupling Synergistic catalysis Cu/M bimetallic catalyst Catalytic mechanism Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Ketones are nearly ideal chemical intermediates due to their high reactivity and relative stability. Other heteroatom functional groups can be easily introduced in ketones at the later stages of syntheses to form various products or intermediates, which have been widely used in the fields of medicines, fertilizers, and organic synthetic chemistry [1,2]. Pd-catalyzed Suzuki-Miyura coupling reaction is one of the most efficient methods to synthetize ketones and has won the 2010 Nobel Prize in chemistry, together with Heck and Negishi couplings [2–6]. But the homogeneous palladium catalysts have many disadvantages except the high costs, such as the preparation processes are complicated, the solvents and ligands used are often toxic, and the product contamination of the residual palladium complexes is inevitable, these shortcomings reduce product quality and hinder the usability of ketones in many fields, especially for pharmaceutical commodities [2,7]. By now, some new types of catalysis modes, such as non-noble single transition metal (Mn, Fe, Cu, Co, and Ni) catalysis [8–14], bifunctional catalysis [15–19], double activation catalysis [20], cascade catalysis [21], synergistic catalysis [22–24] have been gradually used in carbon-carbon coupling reactions. Among them, the synergistic catalysis involving two transition metals is a powerful synthetic strategy for new reaction development. It uses two different transition metal catalysts to activate two separately substrates, then two intermediates interact to afford one chemical transformation. The cooperative of two transition metals not only can improve selectivity to obtain new activity, but also can provide multiple active sites for reaction [25–30]. Recently, the group of N. P. Mankad reported a method to synthesize ketones by using Cu-carbene and Mn-carbonyl co-catalysts for the carbonylative C-C coupling of arylboronic esters with alkyl halides, this reaction can occur at mild conditions with high reactivity and wide substrate compatibility [28]. More interestingly, the cheap and abundant CO was used as the C1 source [28]. As it is known, carbonylation from CO is an efficient method for the synthesis of carbonyl compounds and it has high atomic economy, while the use of CO is comparatively difficult due to its inert and the necessity of high pressure in the transformation [2,4,8,9,31]. In their mechanism study, the possibility that the metal-metal bonded (IPr)Cu-Mn(CO)5 complex might play a role in catalysis as it does in their other studied reactions [32–34] has been ruled out, because they found (IPr)Cu-Mn(CO)5 was unreactive due to the low yield when using (IPr)Cu-Mn(CO)5 as the catalyst. In order to prevent the formation of (IPr)Cu-Mn(CO)5 complex which would induce the concentration of Cu/Mn catalysts, KOMe base was added to remain independent of (IPr)CuOMe and KMn(CO)5. Although the catalytic mechanism of the above reaction has been hypothetical proposed, there are still some questions need to be clarified: (1) Two Mn-carbonyls, Na[Mn(CO)5] and Mn2(CO)10, have been used in Mankad's experiments, these two catalysts should belong different catalytic mechanisms. In the former process, [Mn(CO)5]− is the catalyst and it belongs to a SN2 pathway mechanism. The latter process is a single electron transfer (SET) mechanism through ∙Mn(CO)5 radical after the homolysis of Mn-Mn bond [35–37]. What's the difference between the two mechanisms and which is preferred for the title reaction? (2) For the synergistic catalysis, the co-dependent of two transition metals is important. Except [Mn(CO)5]−1, there are several metal carbony anions, such as FeCp(CO)2 −1, RuCp(CO)2 −1 and Co(CO)4 −1 etc. with distinct nucleophilicities [38], which is the optimum matching to Cu-carbene? In this work, the detailed catalytic mechanisms of carbonylative Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of 4-tolylboronic acid neopentyl glocol ester (Ar-Bneop) and 1-iodooctane (C8H17I) have been investigated using DFT calculations. The main purposes of this study are (1) to clarify the co-dependent catalytic mechanism of title reaction; (2) to determine the Mn-catalyzed cycle prefers to SN2 pathway or SET mechanism; and (3) to reveal the relationship between the reactivity and the nucleophilicities of metal carbony anions. Our results can provide theoretical guideline for new catalysts design for synergistic catalytic functionalization. 2 Computational details All calculations were performed using the Gaussian 09 package [39]. The geometries of all the reactants, complexes, intermediates, products, and transition states were fully optimized at the PBE-D3 [40,41]/def2SVP [42,43] level. PBEPBE density functional is chosen due to it is one of the “fastest” and most cost-effective calculation methods to give the exact geometry. After the D3 dispersion correction, the enthalpy calculations significantly improve to G2MP2 ab initio method [44–46]. The vibration analysis of each optimized stationary point was conducted at the same level to verify the equilibrium structure has no while the transition state has only one imaginary frequency. The intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC) calculations were performed to confirm the connection of each transition state to two relevant minimums [47–49]. To obtain more accurate energy, the single point energies were calculated at both PBE-D3/def2TZVP and M06L [50]/def2TZVP level. The integral equation formalism polarizable continuum model (IEFPCM) [51] was used to consider the solvent effects in both the optimization and energy calculation, with tetrahydrofuran as the solvent. The difference between the Gibbs energies of the reactants and the products (ΔG) were calculated in consideration of IEFPCM model and solution translational entropy correction, the latter calculated using THERMO program [52]. The electronic energies were also calculated at DLPNO-CCSD(T) [53–56]/ def2TZVP/JC [57,58] levels using Orca package [59], the Gibbs energy change in solvent was calculated by the formula proposed by Chamkin et al. [60], G = E gas + G corr + E solv, where E gas was obtained at the DLPNO-CCSD(T) level, G corr and E solv were taken from the corresponding PBE-D3/ def2TZVP calculation. The relative energies calculated by PBE-D3, M06L, and DLPNO-CCSD(T) methods give the similar results, which are listed in Table S1(Supporting Information). The CYLview software was employed to show the 3D structures of the studied species [61]. In order to produce the CPU time, the diisopropylphenyl groups in (IPr)CuOMe (IPr=N, N′-bis(2,6-diisopropylphenyl) imidazol-2-ylidene) are replaced by dimethyl-phenyl groups. 3 Results and discussion Based on the proposed mechanism of N. P. Mankad [28] (Scheme 1), the potential energy surfaces (PES) of the whole reaction are determined. The whole reaction contains two cycles, one is the Ar-Bneop catalyzed by Cu-carbene to generate RO-Bneop and arylcopper LCu-Ar, the other is Mn-carbonyl catalyzed alkyl halide carbonylation through Heck–Breslow cycle to produce RCH2C(O)Mn(CO)5. At last, the LCu-Ar and RCH2C(O)Mn(CO)5, which form from the above two separate cycles, react with each other to produce the final product aryl ketone. The relative Gibbs energies calculated at standard condition (298.15 K and 1 atm) and experimental condition (333.15 K and 3 atm) at PBE-D3/def2TZVP level, all of the results are listed in Table S1 (Supporting Information). All the calculated levels give the similar results; the energies of PBE-D3/def2TZVP at standard condition are used in the following discussion. The optimized xyz coordinates for the stable points on the potential Gibbs-free energy surface are listed in Table S2. 3.1 Cu-catalyzed transformation of Ar-Bneop to RO-Bneop The calculated PES for the reaction of L-Cu-OR and Ar-Bneop, with the optimized geometries and key parameters of the reactants, intermediate, transition state, and products are presented in Fig. 1 . The reaction begins from the electrostatic attraction between the O atom of [Cu] catalyst (A) and the B atom in Ar-Bneop (B), an intermediate Int1 firstly forms, the Gibbs free energy of Int1 is −3.6 kcal/mol. In Int1, the bond angle A(OCu-C) decreases to 143.9° from 173.6° in A. As the reaction proceeding, the O atom of A sequentially approaches the B atom in B, and the Cu-O bond becomes weaken. As the distance between O and B is 1.442 Å and that of Cu and O is 2.374 Å, TS1 arrives. The Gibbs free energy barrier (ΔG#) of TS1 is only 7.4 kcal/mol. After TS1, the O atom continually goes to the B atom, as the same time, the Cu-O bond in A is broken to get RO-Bneop (C) and LCu-Ar (D). The Cu-catalyzed transformation of Ar-Bneop to RO-Bneop is exothermic, the released reaction heat is 6.8 kcal/mol. Therefore, products C and D can produce easily at room temperature, they are thermodynamically stable products. 3.2 Mn-Catalyzed Heck–Breslow cycle for alkyl halide carbonylation In Mankad's experiment, they found both Na[Mn(CO)5] and Mn2(CO)10 have catalytic activities on the alkyl halide carbonylation process [28], and the former shows better catalytic performance than the latter. The former process is C8H17I + [Mn(CO)5]− →C8H17Mn(CO)5 + I−, it belongs to the SN2 substitution pathway. The later process is C8H17I + ·Mn(CO)5 →C8H17Mn(CO)5 + I· and it belongs to the single electron transfer (SET) mechanism. Therefore, two mechanisms, SN2 pathway and SET mechanism are investigated. Because the homolysis of Mn-Mn bond in Mn2(CO)10 can occur easily to get the ∙Mn(CO)5 35–37. In the SET mechanism, it is ∙Mn(CO)5 participates the reaction, whereas in SN2 pathway, it is [Mn(CO)5]−1. 3.2.1 [Mn(CO)5]− catalyzed Heck–Breslow cycle: SN2 mechanism The PES for the [Mn(CO)5]− Heck–Breslow cycle for alkyl halide carbonylation is shown in Fig. 2 . The optimized geometries are presented in Fig. 3 and key parameters of the reactants, complexes, transition states, intermediates, and products are labeled. The SN2 mechanism contains three steps, the first step is the transformations from [Mn(CO)5]− to I−. Then the Mn in [Mn(CO)5]−1 (E) firstly attacks to the C1 atom of CH2I group in C8H17I (F), through TS2i to get Int2 and I−. The energy barrier of TS2i is 11.4 kcal/mol, this step is also is exothermic, the Gibbs free energy change is −6.4 kcal/mol. The following reaction would be the carbonyl insertion process. The direct insertion of CO to the Mn-C1 has been tried but failed. Based on [62], the reaction pathways in which the carbonyl insertion followed by the carbonyl migration process is determined. After Int2, one CO migrates from Mn(CO)5 group to the near C1 atom. In the meantime, the Mn-C1 bond is elongated. As the distance between C of CO and Mn is 1.827 Å and that of CC1 is 1.893 Å, TS3 arrives. After TS3, the distance between CO and C1 decreases, an intermediate Int3 is gotten in which there is a bridge carbonyl. Then, one CO joins into the reaction. This CO can go near to the Mn atom from three directions, below, above, and side of the Mn-C1 bond of Int3. Among them, the pathway in which the CO attacking the Mn atom from the below of Mn-C1 bond has the lowest energy barrier with the value 17.0 kcal/mol (TS4a). The ΔG# (TS4b) of CO from the above of Mn-C1 bond is 25.1 kcal/mol, and that (TS4c) from the side is 26.4 kcal/mol. All of the three ΔG# of TS4a, TS4b, and TS4c are lower than 30.0 kcal/mol, they can occur at the experimental temperature, 60 °C. That is to say, the CO can inserts into the Mn-C1 bond from three directions. Among them, the probability of CO attacking from below direction is the largest. The whole carbonyl insertion process is also exothermic, the reaction heat is −22.0 kcal/mol, an intermediate RCH2(CO)Mn(CO)5 (H) is gotten. In the carbonyl insertion process, because CO is used as the C1 source, it can be expected that the high pressure of CO would help to improve the conversion of this step. Our calculation is consistent with Mankad's experimental conditions, high CO pressure (3 atm). Similar reaction conditions have also been reported by Ingold's group [63], their work found that under CO atomosphere (10 atm), the alkyl iodides were known to undergo carbonylation rapidly and reversibly. The triplet PES of Mn-Catalyzed Heck–Breslow cycle has been also investigated. The triplet Gibbs free energy profile and the geometries of stationary points on the triplet PES are shown in Fig. S1 (Supporting Information). As it is shown, the Gibbs free energy of triplet Mn(CO)5 − are much higher than that of singlet state, 44.3 kcal/mol. Moreover, the whole triplet PES is above that of singlet PES. Thus, the reaction only could occur on the single PES. Mankad's radical clock experiments indicated that alkyl radical form with sufficient lifetime to undergo radical rearrangements [28], the work of Watanabe did support alkyl radical formation on the basis of ESR measurements, R∙ and ∙Mn(CO)5 were detected [64]. These results mean that SET mechanism is possible between Mn(CO)5 − and C8H17I. Therefore, the reaction pathway initiated by SET mechanism is also investigated based on Scheme 2 [64,65]. In this pathway, the first step is the SET process, R-I + ∙Mn(CO)5 − → [RI∙− ∙IMn(CO)5], this step is endothermic. The Gibbs energy change of this step is 11.9 kcal/mol, this means that the process can proceed easily. The calculated dissociation energy of [RI∙− ∙IMn(CO)5] pair to RI∙− and ·Mn(CO)5 is 24.6 kcal/mol, the energy indicated that the formed RI∙− and ·Mn(CO)5 are caged. In [RI∙− ∙IMn(CO)5] pair, the interaction between I− and R is weak, therefore, I− is easily released to form [R∙ ∙Mn(CO)5] pair, the Gibbs energy change is only 7.7 kcal/mol. Our calculation results are consistent with the ESR results of Watanabe et. al, the R∙ and ∙Mn(CO)5 radicals does exists in the reaction process [64]. The energy change of R-I + ∙Mn(CO)5 − to [RI∙− ∙IMn(CO)5] is 19.6 kcal/mol, it means that the reaction can occur at Mankad's experimental conditions [28], which the absorbed energy is higher than the energy barrier of SN2 pathway, therefore, the SN2 mechanism is dominant. 3.2.3 ∙Mn(CO)5 catalyzed Heck–Breslow cycle: SET mechanism The PES profiles of SET mechanism are also shown in Fig. 2 and the geometries of stationary points on the PES are in Fig. 3. For the SET mechanism, one possible reaction pathway is the ∙Mn(CO)5 attacking the C8H17I (F), through TS2r to get Int2 and I∙, the energy barrier ΔG# of TS2r is 17.7 kcal/mol, After Int2, the reaction processes are just the same as those on the SN2 pathway. The geometry of TS2r is similar to that of TS2i, the difference is the bond length of Mn-C1. In TS2r, the bond length of Mn-C1 is 2.566 Å, which is shorter than that in TS2i (2.988 Å). In summary, the SET mechanism follows the pathway of ∙Mn(CO)5+ F→TS2i→Int2+ I∙, the energy barriers of this pathway are within 20.0 kcal/mol, thus, the SET mechanism can occur easily at the experimental conditions. Our calculation results are consistent with the experimental results of Mankad's group [28]. 3.3 C-C coupling process In Mankad's experiment [28], the desired ketone formed in THF solvent in the presence of KOMe. In this polar condition, [Mn(CO) 5]− (E) can easily dissociate from H, the produced RCH2(CO) interacts with OMe− in solvent to get the stable ester RCH2(CO)OMe (K). Then, K reacts with D, which gotten from the Cu-catalyzed transformation of Ar-Bneop to RO-Bneop, to get the last product RCH2(CO)Ar (J). The catalyst, Cu-OR (A), is reproduced. The PES of C-C cross-coupling is shown in Fig. 4 . In this step, the Cu atom of D interacts with the C atom of CO group in RCH2(CO) and the O atom in OCH3. Two triangle structures form in TS5. The Gibbs free energy barrier of this step is 26.2 kcal/mol. Therefore, this step can proceed at the experimental conditions, 60 °C [28]. Except the C-C coupling reaction between D and K, another possibility is that LCuAr directly reacts with C8H17C(O)-Mn(CO)5(H). Mankad et al. has investigated the reaction between LCuAr and H in the absence of KOMe, they found that the expected ketone product J can formed under an atmosphere of CO (3 atm), if under N2, no J was observed. The PES profile of direct C-C coupling between D and H is shown in Fig S2. As it is shown, the coupling between D and H contains two steps. The first is one CO dissociated from Mn(CO)5 to form the activate site. There are three sites of CO in H, as shown in Fig. S3, the CO at 1 site is the easiest to dissociate with the dissociation energy of 18.6 kcal/mol. After the CO dissociation, the Mn(CO)4 group in RC(O)-Mn(CO)4 attack the Cu atom in LCuAr to get J via TS6. The energy barrier of this reaction pathway is 27.9 kcal/mol, at the meaning time, LCu- Mn(CO)4 is obtained. The energy barrier of the coupling of D and H is a litter higher than that of D and K, and the formation of Cu-Mn bond would reduce the concentration of active catalyst, which has been proven by Mankad's experiment. Therefore, RC(O)-OMe should be the real electrophile reacting with LCuAr under catalytic conditions D to get the product. In total, the carbonylative Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of arylboronic esters with alkyl halides catalyzed by Cu/Mn bimetallic synergistic catalysts contains three steps, Cu-carbene catalyzed Ar-Bneop to generate RO-Bneop and arylcopper LCu-Ar, Mn-carbonyl catalyzed alkyl halide carbonylation through Heck–Breslow cycle to produce RCH2(CO)Mn(CO)5. The product aryl ketone is gotten through the C-C cross coupling between LCu-Ar and RCH2(CO)OCH3, which form from the above cycles. The whole reaction is exothermic, the C-C coupling process is the rate-determining step, the Gibbs free energy barrier of this step is 26.2 kcal/mol. Therefore, the need temperature is about 60 °C. Our calculation results provide a detail mechanism for the title reaction and are consistent with the experimental results of Mankad et al. [28]. 3.4 Computational screening of Cu/M catalysts In the Mankad's former studies [37,61], they synthesized and characterized a series of (NHC)Cu-[M] heterobimetallic complexes by the addition of (NHC)CuCl to transition metal (TM = Cr, Mo, W) carbonyl anions, such as [FeCp(CO)2]−, [RuCp(CO)2]−, [Mn(CO)5]−, [CrCp(CO)3]−, [MoCp(CO)3]−, [WCp(CO)3]− and [Co(CO)4]−. These [M]− anions have different nucleophilicity, range from 7 × 107 to 1 [37]. These compounds also show different activity and selectivity in catalytic reactions [66–70]. In this part, three more typical [M]− anion with distinct nucleophilicity are chosen in addition to [Mn(CO)5]−, they are [FeCp(CO)2]−, [RuCp(CO)2]−, and [Co(CO)4]−, the nucleophilicity is 70,000,000, 7,500,000, 77 and 1 for [FeCp(CO)2]−, [RuCp(CO)2]−, [Mn(CO)5]−, and [Co(CO)4]−, respectively. Because the [M]– only participates the Heck–Breslow cycle for alkyl halide carbonylation, and the energies of triplet [M]– are much higher than those of singlet states (Table S3, Supporting Information), the singlet PES of Heck–Breslow cycle catalyzed by the four anions are shown in Fig. 5 . As shown in Fig. 5, the reaction mechanisms catalyzed by four different catalysts are similar. All of them contain electron transfer, CO migration, and CO insertion processes. The whole PESs of the C-C cross coupling catalyzed by [FeCp(CO)2]− and [RuCp(CO)2]−, are below those catalyzed by [Mn(CO)5]− and [Co(CO)4]−. Compared to [Mn(CO)5]−, the energy barriers of the reaction pathway catalyzed by [Co(CO)4]− decrease slightly, with the ΔG# of 15.9 kcal/mol. It is smaller than the ΔG# of [Mn(CO)5]− catalyzed cycle, 17.0 kcal/mol for CO insertion process. Therefore, it can be concluded that [Co(CO)4]− would show the similar catalytic performance to [Mn(CO)5]−. The uses of [Co(CO)4]− as the catalyst for the reaction of alkyl halides, CO, and alcohols have been reported in the former experimental studies [71–73]. As the pioneer, Heck et al. used Na[Co(CO)4]− for carbonylation reactions of alkyl halides in 1963 [71]. Since then, the Co- and Mn-carbonyl catalysts were used for alkyl halide carbonylation [72,73]. These experimental studies can prove our conclusion that the weak nucleophile [Co(CO)4]− has the similar catalytic performance to the [Mn(CO)5]−. The [Co(CO)4]− and [Mn(CO)5]− would enable carbonylative C-C coupling with the arylcopper generated from the Cu-catalyzed cycle to get the last product, ketones. Although the whole PESs of the C-C cross coupling catalyzed by [FeCp(CO)2]− and [RuCp(CO)2]− are below those catalyzed by [Mn(CO)5]− and [Co(CO)4]−. The low relative energies of Int2-Fe and Int2-Ru make the energy barriers of TS4-Ru and TS4-Fe increase to 24.2 and 25.5 kcal/mol, therefore, the rates of the reactions catalyzed by [FeCp(CO)2]− and [RuCp(CO)2]− are lower than those catalyzed by [Mn(CO)5]− and [Co(CO)4]−. Int2-Fe and Int2-Ru are more stable than Int2-Mn and Int2-Co, the main reason is their different anion nucleophilicities. The anion nucleophilicities of [FeCp(CO)2]− and [RuCp(CO)2]− are much larger than those of [Mn(CO)5]− and [Co(CO)4]−, therefore, [FeCp(CO)2]− and [RuCp(CO)2]− have more tendency to interacts with C8H17 +. The calculated binding energies of [M]-C8H17 in Int2-M are 142.4 kcal/mol, 141.3 kcal/mol, 113.0 kcal/mol, and 105.8 kcal/mol for M= Ru, Fe, Mn and Co, respectively. Thus, the energies of Int2-Fe and Int2-Ru are much lower than those of Int2-Mn and Int2-Co. In another word, the larger of nucleophilicity the [M]− anion has, the stronger interaction would be between [M]− and C8H17 +, the reaction has the lower energy of Int2-M and the higher energy barrier of TS4. For the synergistic catalysis, the match of two cycles, which mean that the reaction rates are close, is important. Otherwise, the whole reaction would delay, or the by-product would produce. Based on the above discussion, it can be concluded that the anions with the very large nucleophilicity are not convenient for the reaction. On the contrary, the metal carbonyl anions with moderate even low nucleophilicity are suited to use for the co-catalysis with the Cu-carbene catalyst. 4 Conclusions Based on DFT calculation, the reactions of Ar-Bneop with C8H17I catalyzed by Cu/Mn synergistic catalyst was studied. The following conclusions can be drawn. The whole reaction contains two cycles, one is the Cu-carbene catalyzed Ar-Bneop to generate RO-Bneop and arylcopper LCu-Ar, the other is Mn-carbonyl catalyzed alkyl halide carbonylation through Heck–Breslow cycle to produce RCH2(CO)Mn(CO)5. At the final step, the LCu-Ar and RCH2(CO)Mn(CO)5, formed from the above separate two cycles, react with each other to produce the final product aryl ketone. For the Mn-carbonyl catalyzed alkyl halide carbonylation process, the Na[Mn(CO)5] is more suitable to catalyze the title reaction than ∙Mn(CO)5. Furthermore, the metal carboxyl anions with very large nucleophilicity are not convenient for the reaction, those with moderate even low nucleophilicity are suited to use for the co-catalysis with the Cu-carbene catalyst. Our calculation results are consistent with and provide explanations for the experimental observations. It is hoped that our study could shed some light on the further development of bimetallic catalyzed carbonylative Suzuki-Miyaura coupling and for the screening of other heterobimetallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Carbonylative Suzuki-Miyura coupling reaction is one of the most efficient methods to synthetize ketones. In this work, the reaction mechanism of arylboronic esters with alkyl halides catalyzed by Cu/Mn synergistic catalysts has been studied by DFT calculation. The calculated results show that the whole reaction contains two cycles, one is the Cu-catalyzed transformation of Ar-Bneop to RO-Bneop, and the other is Mn-catalyzed Heck–Breslow cycle for alkyl halide carbonylation. At the last step, the final product aryl ketone is produced through the C-C cross-coupling between the two intermediates, which form from the above separate two cycles. For the title reaction, the [Mn(CO)5]− catalyzed the Heck–Breslow cycle belongs to SN2 mechanism, and Mn2(CO)10 catalyzed cycle is SET mechanism. In addition to [Mn(CO)5]−, the metal carbonyl anions with moderate even low nucleophilicity are suitable to co-catalyze the carbonylative Suzuki-Miyaura coupling with the Cu-carbene catalyst. Our calculation results are consistent with and provide explanations the experimental observations, as well as shed lights on further advancement of new bimetallic catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanistic insights and computational design of Cu/M bimetallic synergistic catalysts for Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of arylboronic esters with alkyl halides
